publicationStmt.p: File created by Evolving Hands project, Newcastle University

div.ab:
Baghdad June 30
Received
10 August 1921
1921
Darling Father. It's being so frightfully interesting -
there! there! let me begin at the beginning. Where was I?
It was Monday's vernacular paper which gave the first full
account of Faisal's arrival at Basrah + the quite admirable
speech which he made at a big function they had for him.
Tumbling in on this came an agent whom I had sent down
to Basrah to bring me a report of the temper of his reception
+ gave a very glowing account of the effect made by the speech
which he said inclined all hearts towards Faisal. This was
cheering + in the evening Naji Suwaidi + Nuri dropped in
after tea, Naji back from Basrah with a rosy tale. Then
we fell a-talking of the next steps + agreed that we
couldn't leave him here not knowing what his position
would be for 6 or 8 weeks till the electionsLikely refers to the plebiscite, or referendum, held in the Summer of 1921, where citizens voted on the form of government and head of state. The results were overwhelmingly in favour of Faisal in the role of Sharif. were over.
Somehow or other the country must be got to declare itself.
Sir Percy + I had already discussed this but I didn't feel
at liberty to mention the fact to my two friends, so I only
gave them comforting reassurances. But I don't want Faisal
to come in by a coup d'état of the extremists - we
must have something much more constitutional than that.
Tuesday I was busy helping the Mutasarrif to get out his
invitations to a big dinner which is to be given by the
Municipality tonight. In the evening I went to a library
committee meeting after which Sasun Eff + I motored to
the SaraiIt’s not certain what Bell is referring to as the term Sarai has multiple meanings, but it is perhaps reference to a government building. to see Faisal's lodging which was very satisfactory
- big rooms in a Govt Government building on the river. On Wed. Wednesday
Faisal was to arrive at 7 a.m. Col. Joyce + I motored
to the station together, going all up the big street to the
upper bridge. The whole town was decorated, triumphal
arches, Arab flags + packed with people in the street, on
the housetops, everywhere. At the station immense crowds. It
was very well arranged with seats for the Magnates all

had Mr Philby been at any special pains to conceal
from Faisal an opinion which is variance from what he
knows to be the policy of H. M. G. His Majesty's Government Naturally Faisal was
bewildered - was the High Commissioner with him + if so
why did his officers adopt a different attitude? All the
more was he bewildered because he was told with equal
frequency that if the local officers would lift a finger
all the people would follow their lead. Why wasn't the
finger lifted if that was the official policy? We
explained all that had happened, + the long delay in
getting the pronouncement from England, + that Sir Percy
was absolutely sound + determined to carry the thing
through; + with that I left them to dress for a ministerial
dinner given by the Naqib for Faisal in Faisal's house!
an odd arrangement. The Naqib was represented by one
of the minsters; Sir Percy was there + Sir Aylmer - it
was a jejune affair I fancy.
I, walking home in the dark, was hailed by a friendly
chauffeur who knew me + asked if I wanted a lift
home. And it was the beflagged + beflowered car
in which Faisal had driven from the station! So I
next occupied it + arrived home in it to the stupefaction supifaction
of my servants. The chauffeur told me that when
Faisal came out of the station the crowd surged round
him. He was hurried into the car + then the chauffeur
saw a man in white robes with a black beard
doing his level best to get in after him. Heaven
inspired him with an idea that Faisal ought to go
alone, so he clapped the door to + drove off. And
the man - don't I know him! - was a certain
ShaikhAhmad Daud, one of the emptiest windbags

round, + all filled with magnates. Sir Percy intilt +
Sir Aylmer + a guard of honour + all. But - we
learnt there had been an éboulement on the line - a
telegram had been received to say he was coming in by
motor + hoped to arrive at the appointed hour.
We waited, we talked, we shook hands all round
- at least I did - we looked at the Arab Levies
+ towards 8 paf! came a message down the line
to say that he was in the train after all, couldn't
get through + might be there at midday! Sir Percy
quickly took command. Noon at the end of June is
not an hour at which you can hold a great
reception out of doors. Moreover it wasn't by any
means certain that he would arrive at noon. He
was accordingly asked to spend the day in the train
+ get in at 6 p.m. And we all went home! I to
the office where presently Nuri came in + assured me
that the evening's reception would be better even than
that of the morning. Then Haji Naji, up from Basrah 2
days before, full of delight. Thanks to the letter I had
given him to Mr Cornwallis he had spoken to Faisal, +
he was the King they wanted + that was all right!
Darling old thing. So behold us at 5.30 again setting
off to the station. This time Sasun Eff took me. The
town was unbelievably more crowded than before - I
missed
scarcely thought we should get through. However we did, +
arrived to kind the station similarly much fuller of
people. And this time the train arrived.
SidiArabic title of respect often used to mean 'saint' or 'my lord/master'. Faisal stood at the carriage door looking very
splendid in full Arab dress, saluting the guard of honour.

Sir Percy + Sir Aylmer went up to him as he got out + gave
him a fine ceremonious greeting, + all the people clapped.
He went down the line of the guard of honour, inspecting it
+ I espied Mr Cornwallis stepping out of the carriage, looking
rather glum, so I went + received him, + Lord! I was
glad to see him! While we talked Sidi Faisal came back
+ Sir Percy began to present the Arab magnates, representatives
of the Naqib etc. I hid behind Mr Cornwallis but Faisal
saw me + stepped across to shake hands with me. He
looked excited + anxious - you're not a king on approbation
without any tension of the spirit - but it only gave his
natural dignity a more human charm. Then he was lost in
the crowd + Col. Joyce + I stayed talking to Mr Cornwallis
who, poor dear, was so dried up with thirst that he
could scarcely talk at all. But what he said was that
up to now things hadn't gone well. The people were standing
back, above all, the Political Officers were standing back
(this part isn't to be repeated!) + Mr Philby was the
worst. Fortunately he was down with fever at Hillah!
So I parked Mr C. into Sasun's motor + we set off for
the Maude bridge. But don't think we got there. In the first
quarter of an hour we got perhaps half way + then
stuck fast in the traffic. And there was Mr Cornwallis
dying of thirst. We abandoned the motor + walked to
Mr Garbett's house, near the Maude bridge on the left
bank, + having had abundance of sodas Mr Garbett,
Mr Cornwallis + I sat on the garden terrace over
the river + talked for an hour.
All the way up the story they had heard was: the
High Commissioner is neutral, the KhatunHonorific title given to Bell. + Mr Garbett
want Faisal + Mr Philby wants a republic, nor apparently

in Mesopotamia, a leader of last year's RebellionIraqi Revolt of 1920 against the British suppressed by the British using heavy artillery and aerial bombardment. released
under the amnestyAmnesty issued by the British government in which those imprisoned for their involvement in the 1920 Iraqi revolt were pardoned. + now an object of universal
ridicule. Fancy what a companion that would
have been with whom to make a début! The
chauffeur was longing to tell his tale + he found a
good audience in me. "He didn't seem very sure at first"
he said "+ I couldn't get along. The people clung
to the car + surged in between me + the escort.
But when we got into the big street the police
opened the way. I went very slow + he stood up
in the car + the people shouted + shouted + he
saluted all the time. All the way from the Maude
Bridge to the Sarai - he did seem pleased!"
So that was how he came to Baghdad.
This morning on my way to the office I went to the
Sarai + gave by card to Faisal's ADCAide-De-Camp. He said would
I wait a moment - the AmirTitle given to rulers or military leaders. would like to see me;
it was only a little past 7, rather early for a
morning call. I waited, talking to the ADC + presently
Faisal sent for me. They showed me into a big room +
he came quickly across in his long white robes, took
me by both hands + said "I couldn't have believed
that you could have given me as much help as you
have given me." So we sat down on a sofa + he
told me his doubts + I comforted him + assured
him that Sir Percy was absolutely with him. Then he
asked me whether he should call on the Naqib - Mr
Cornwallis had told us he was very reluctant to do so.
"I'll make you responsible" he said. I answered that
I thought he had better go, we owed the Naqib a debt
of gratitude + it would make things easier for Sir Percy

alluded to Faisal as King of the 'Iraq + everyone clapped +
cheered. And then there stepped forward into the grassy space
between the tables a shi'ahAn Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam. in white robes + a black cloak
+ big black turban + chanted a poem of which I didn't
understand a word. It was far too long + as I say quite
unintelligible but nevertheless it was wonderful. The tall,
robed figure chanting + marking time with an uplifted
hand, the starry darkness + the palm trees beyond the
illuminated circle - it hypnotized you. But dear, dear,
the evening wasn't without its funny moments - as
for instance when in the middle of dinner 'Abdul Majid
finding verity in his unaccustomed lemonade - he's
+ great toper as a rule - confided to me that he
did hate the Shi'ahs! And after dinner Shaikh Ahmad
Daud, the old ass, went up to Sir Aylmer + shook
him warmly by the hand. Sir A.Aylmer hadn't an idea
who he was but Sasun Eff, standing by explained
+ translated. "Well, well" said Sh.Shaikh Ahmad "just
this time last year we were beginning the rebellion,
but I like it better this way. Yes I would rather
exchange compliments with you than bullets." I must
till you that Sh. Ahmad never exchanged any
bullets, for we caught him + sent him off to
languish at Henjam.
They formed a circle under the palm trees + sat Faisal
down in the middle of it - + then left him! So again
I stepped into the breach + brought people up to him
till Abdul Majid took the cue + began introducing
people himself. But the introductions were seriously
hampered by the wearisome speeches our orators
would insist on making. I disappeared into the outskirts

He said "If Sir Percy is with me I'll go + see the porter
but if he isn't with me I should like to leave tomorrow!"
Then I gave him a little advice about people,
that he was to be very polite to the Mosul deputation, that
he wasn't to allow any one to be in his car with
him, + above all that he was to speak out all his
mind to Sir Percy.
And as I left I saw Shaikh Ahmad Daud sitting in the
ante chamber! However Faisal is not a man on
whom a warning is wasted.
Mr Cornwallis came in to the office later + I told
him I had called on Faisal. He said (I must tell
you this because it pleased me so much) "That was
quite right. All the way up he has been hearing
your praise + he gave me a message for you in case
he didn't see you to speak to today - I was to tell
you how grateful he was." And my private spy, the
man I sent to Basrah, tells me the people constantly
say "Is the KhatunHonorific title given to Bell. satisfied?"
Later in the morning in rolled Shaikh 'Ali Sulaiman
of the Dulaim from Ramadi, the staunchest opponent
whom Faisal has had. I've wrestled with him long
in speech + letter. He brought the next most important
DulaimLarge Sunni Arab royal tribe. shaikh with him. Mr Cornwallis was with
me + I introduced him as having come with
Faisal. 'Ali Sulaiman sat down + announced that
he had that minute arrived by motor from Ramadi
+ had come straight to me. I said "Where should
you come first if not to me?" so matters being on

this pleasant footing we talked of Faisal + Mr Cornwallis
said very tactful things. 'Ali Sulaiman has come in to see
Faisal! I took him up to Sir Percy + left him in
his wise hands.
July 2. The next event was that evening's banquet in the Maude
gardens.Maude Gardens perhaps refers to gardens located near the Maude Bridge in Baghdad. It was really beautifully done. The place, lighted with electric
lights looked lovely. But I really shall have to set about getting
a proper ceremonial for Faisal's court - when he has one
- for they none of them have the least idea what to do
next. He came in, shook hands with Sir Percy, the General,
Lady Cox + me, + then relapsed onto a sofa + talked to me
as the one person handy to talk to - he speaks no English
+ only a very little French. I felt this wouldn't do at all
with everyone dying to be introduced to him, + as no one
made a move I asked him if I might bring up people
to him + then brought Mrs Slater, Mrs Garbett, Mr Tod +
any one who happened to be round, till we went in to
dinner. The tables were arranged in a large square;
at the top table we sat like this:
Sasun
diagram of table seating plan
Sir P.
Faisal
Sir Aylmer
Mr Cornwallis
GLB
Mayor
Abdul Maji
Shawi
Lady Cox
Ja'far
Faisal carried on a little conversation in French with Sir
Aylmer, but mostly he + I + Sir Percy + Abdul Majid + I talked
across the table. Faisal looked very happy + I felt very happy
+ so did Sir Percy. As for 'Abdul Majid he has fallen flat
before Faisal. After the dinner 'Abdul Majid made a little speech
+ then a young man recited a horribly dull poem, + then
got up our great poet, of whom I've often told you, Jamil
Zahawi, + recited a tremendous ode in which he repeatedly

+ talked to people - I must tell you that an immense
tail had by now assembled - but poor Faisal
when at last he shook himself free + got up to
go, came to me + said "I used to do all I could to
avoid speeches in Syria + I'm afraid they are going to be
much worse here!" Before he went I got all the other
English people + their wives introduced to him, explaining
to him who each one was. And then at 11 o'clock we
came away.
A terrific lot of people came to see me next day, + late.
in the afternoon 'Ali Sulaiman came to my house + sat down
solidly. "Well" he said "you were right. I've seen him +
he's the man for us." He had won 'Ali's heart, apparently,
by telling him he didn't intend to move a step without
Sir Percy's advice. After that I went out riding.
But it's not all smooth yet. We get reports about the
lower Euphrates tribes preparing monstrous petitions in
favour of a republic + of the Shi'ahAn Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
'alimsRefers to an educated scholar of Islamic law. + mujtahidsRefers to a person accepted as an original authority in Islamic law.
being all against Faisal - I don't believe half of them
are true but they keep one in anxiety. Today I sent
for one of the principal Euphrates shaikhs - Abdul Wahid
with whom you had lunch that day we went on the
river from Najaf. He's a strong SharifianTerm referring to things related to the Sharif (a title used to describe those - usually royal - claiming descent from the prophet Muhammad), here referring to a person supportive of a form of government headed by a Sharif, in this case Faisal. + we talked
the whole matter over. Before him I had had an
influential little group of Baghdadis saying that we must
finish the business, we couldn't wait for elections. Somehow
or other Faisal must be proclaimed King. I referred them to
Faisal himself, knowing that he has discussed it with
Sir Percy, + told them to take Faisal's orders. In the
afternoon Faisal sent for me + told me his ideas which
were very sound. I also gave him a few suggestions to bring
before Sir Percy. He complained bitterly of Mr Philby + I don't

think Mr Philby will be able to stay. I'm very sorry, but it is
his own fault. With that Faisal went off to see Sir Percy
so I should think things will happen. I'm beginning
to feel as if I couldn't stand it much longer! One is straining
every nerve all the time to pull the matter forward;
talking, persuading, writing - I find myself carrying on
the argument even in my sleep. But any way Faisal's
ante chamber contained a good many of the right people
+ it's comforting to think that he can do the talking so well
himself. We've got Baghdad + I'm pretty certain we
have got Mosul; the rest will fall into line.
Sunday July 3. I went riding early with Mr Tod - to Haji Naji's
where we sat + eat a melon + excellent apricots - + directly
after breakfast I returned the call of the Mosul deputationThe leading people of Mosul who came forward in support of proclaiming Faisal as king.
who had come to see me on their arrival. We sat in the
courtyard of the hotel + they explained that they wanted to
invite Faisal to Mosul + therefore wanted permission for the
Municipality to spend what was necessary on his
entertainment. I think I can get the thing arranged for
them. They had been dining with Faisal the night before
+ seemed much pleased with him + themselves.
I've letters from
Mother
+
you
of June 1 + 2 +
Heaven be praised Reuter tells us the strikeLikely refers to the 1921 coal strike, which was ended on the 28th June when the Government agreed to subsidise the coal industry. is over but I'm
very very anxious to know whether the terms accepted are
reasonable.
Ever your very affectionate daughter
Gertrude

On His Majesty's Service.
30 June
10 August
1921
Sir Hugh Bell Bart.
C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
ARAB BUREAU,
BAGHDAD .
G L Bell
